titleproper.value: Guide to the Harry Hakam Papers <num>ALBA.046</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Processed by Wendy Scheir

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2017-07-20T15:42:18</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Harry Hakam (1913-1996) was an electrician and union activist who fought with the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War as a machine-gunner, a runner, and an electrician, taking part in the Jarama, Brunete and Aragon offensives. The collection consists of materials dating from Hakam's time in Spain, including correspondence and propaganda graphics; as well as materials relating to post-Spanish Civil War political events in Spain, and the activities of Spanish Civil War veterans.

p.value: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
In World War II, Hakam was a frogman in the U.S. Navy, and afterward he continued a career as a journeyman electrician and union activist. He died in 1996.

<emph render="bold">Series II: Subject Files, 1961-1988</emph>. This series consists of materials relating to post-Spanish Civil War political events in Spain, and the activities of Spanish Civil War veterans. Of note is a 1961 Life Magazine article featuring a photograph of Hakam taken in Spain; and a playbill from a Lincoln Center fiftieth anniversary tribute to American veterans of the Spanish Civil War. Many of the articles and other materials about Spanish politics and the veterans' return visits to Spain are in Spanish and Catalan.
